nodes.text: There is a systemic relationship between high public debt levels and macroeconomic outcomes, specifically economic growth and inflation
Method: Constructed and used a new historical multi-country dataset on central government gross public debt covering 44 countries and about 200 years with over 3,700 annual observations

Method: Supplemented public debt data with gross external debt data (public and private) from World Bank and other sources; external debt time series for advanced countries too short to compute long historical thresholds
Assumption: Public debt is measured as gross central government debt; domestic public debt is issued under domestic jurisdiction; public debt excludes debts merely carrying a government guarantee
Result: Since 2007 public debt rose sharply—about 75 percent increase for five crisis countries between 2007 and 2009 and about 20 percent increase for non-crisis countries

Evidence: For 20 advanced economies (1946–2009) observations, median GDP growth is roughly 1 percentage point lower when public debt/GDP exceeds about 90 percent; mean growth is nearly 4 percentage points lower
Evidence: Long-run (up to two centuries) data for advanced countries show mean growth about 1.7 percent when debt exceeds 90 percent versus 3.7 percent when debt is below 30 percent

Evidence: For emerging markets, high public debt (>90 percent of GDP) is associated with lower median growth (e.g., median falls to about 2.9 percent) and much higher inflation (median inflation rises from under 7 percent to about 16 percent)
Claim: The recent large increases in public debt are likely to be an enduring legacy of the 2007–2009 financial crisis and could have long-term macroeconomic consequences
Conclusion: Across both advanced and emerging economies, very high public debt/GDP levels (about 90 percent and above) are associated with notably lower growth outcomes
Result: External gross debt in emerging markets shows lower growth thresholds—growth declines markedly when external debt exceeds 60 percent of GDP and can halve or become negative above 90 percent
Limitation: Cannot calculate long-run external debt thresholds for advanced economies because external debt time series for advanced countries only begin around 2000

Claim: The nonlinear deterioration of growth as debt approaches historical boundaries is consistent with debt intolerance and may be mediated by sharply rising market interest rates forcing fiscal adjustment or default
Claim: For advanced economies there is no systematic relationship between high public debt and higher inflation as a group, though individual country exceptions exist

Claim: Private sector deleveraging after financial crises (private debt declines) is common and can further dampen medium-term growth, illustrating that public and private debt dynamics jointly affect recovery
Policy implication: Excessive reliance on short-term borrowing increases vulnerability to confidence crises; prudent debt management and attention to maturity structure should be policy priorities
